summary: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland that produces excess catecholamines, leading to symptoms such as hypertension, headaches, and palpitations. It can also occur outside the adrenal glands as a paraganglioma. While often benign, a small percentage can be malignant. Diagnosis relies on biochemical tests and imaging, and treatment typically involves surgical removal of the tumor.
causes: RET proto-oncogene (p.C634W) associated with Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
symptoms: Episodic fits of pain concentrated in the abdomen
Hectic flush distinctly marked on each cheek
diagnosis: Incidental imaging (computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging)
Biochemical tests (catecholamine blood test, catecholamines - urine)
treatments: Treatment for progressive metastatic pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas (e.g., (177)Lu-DOTATATE)
